Schemas are an important piece of data d: Schemas are an important piece of data documentation. Schemas work together with a dataset and describe data features such as column names, units, and descriptions etc.
Using the tools of the Semantic Engine y: Using the tools of the Semantic Engine you can write human- and machine-readable schemas.
and use it to test schema tools such as: and use it to test schema tools such as viewing, editing, and creating a Data Entry Excel.

Use your machine-readable schema bundle: Use your machine-readable schema bundle to help you collect schema conformant data, or to verify that data you have collected follows the rules in the schema. Verifying data is an important step in your analysis.

also supports data verification. Upload: also supports data verification. Upload a schema and a dataset and you can verify your dataset against the data rules in the schema.
Welcome to Agri-food Data Canada's schem: Welcome to Agri-food Data Canada's schema writer for helping researchers write better, machine-actionable, context for their research data.
Briefly, schemas describe the attributes: Briefly, schemas describe the attributes (variable names/column headers) of your dataset and help make your data more useful (more FAIR). Using the Agri-food Data Canada schema editor, you can write a schema for your data sets. Using the language of Overlays Capture Architecture (OCA) you can easily write human- and machine-actionable descriptions of your data which you can store with your data, share with your data or deposit with your data. If your schema is of general interest you can also deposit it to be cited as an independent research object, contributing to data standardization and interoperability.
To learn more about schemas and the OCA: To learn more about schemas and the OCA schema specification
read our introduction on the ADC webpage: read our introduction on the ADC webpage.
Watch our tutorial and see an example sc: Watch our tutorial and see an example schema being created:
Enter the name of each attribute below: Enter the name of each attribute below
This will be the column header in every: This will be the column header in every tabular data set no matter what language.
Every attribute must be unique, and no e: Every attribute must be unique, and no entries can be left blank.
This page is where you can write the met: This page is where you can write the metadata describing the schema you are writing. Metadata helps people find, understand, and use your schema. If you name and describe your schema descriptions in general terms, it will be easier for you and others to reuse the schema for different datasets. This will help with ensuring your data is more interoperable.
Each column of your dataset is an attrib: Each column of your dataset is an attribute in your schema. Here you can add more details about each attribute to help people understand and use your dataset.
Entry codes are options you want availab: Entry codes are options you want available to users as a list of choices for a specific attribute. For example, to limit gender entry to one of three choices you can use entry codes M, F, and X. Then for the English entries you can enter Male, Female and Other. If you have another language such as French, you could use Masculin, Féminin, and Autre as labels for the entry code.
You can add details in each language to: You can add details in each language to help users of your schema. By having languages separate from the underlying structure it means you can share your schema in multiple languages.
Before finishing your schema you can pre: Before finishing your schema you can preview the final contents on this page.
Character encoding of the data source (f: Character encoding of the data source (for each attribute). If you don’t know what the data source uses you can leave this blank. If you are creating a schema for new data a good choice would be UTF-8.
Specify if the underlying data must have: Specify if the underlying data must have an entry for the specific attribute.
Add Format Rules for Data Entry: Add Format Rules for Data Entry
Add Entry Limit Rules for Data Entry: Add Entry Limit Rules for Data Entry
Please enter a unique attribute name for: Please enter a unique attribute name for each attribute
Please enter a Type for all attributes: Please enter a Type for all attributes
Please enter a unique attribute name: Please enter a unique attribute name
Attribute names cannot be blank. Please: Attribute names cannot be blank. Please fill out all names before continuing.
All attribute names must be unique befor: All attribute names must be unique before proceeding
This is the name for the attribute and,: This is the name for the attribute and, for example, will be the column header in every tabular data set no matter what language.
The units of each attribute (or leave bl: The units of each attribute (or leave blank if the attribute is not a measurement and has no units).
Rather than allow free text entry into a: Rather than allow free text entry into a record, you may wish to limit entries to one of a few in a list. For example, you may wish to create a list of choices for gender, or for experimental farm name, or for species. You will then be able to create entries for your list that will be part of the schema.
If the attribute could be considered Per: If the attribute could be considered Personally Identifiable Information (PII) you can flag the attribute here. This will be documented in the schema and downstream users of your schema will understand they need to take care of the data that has been flagged.
Examples of PII include names, locations: Examples of PII include names, locations, postal codes, telephone numbers, identifying genetic data, race, gender, ethnicity, etc.
Rather than allow free text entry into a: Rather than allow free text entry into a record, you may wish to limit entries to one of a few in a list. For example, you may wish to create a list of choices for gender, or for experimental farm name, or for species. You will then be able to create entries for your list that will be part of the schema.
a data type where the data only has two: a data type where the data only has two possible variables: true or false
a data type that defines a binary code s: a data type that defines a binary code signal
a data type that defines dates. Common f: a data type that defines dates. Common formats include dates (e.g., YYYY-MM-DD), times (e.g., hh:mm:ss), dates and times concatenated (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss.sss+zz:zz), and durations (e.g., PnYnMnD)
a data type that defines a structure tha: a data type that defines a structure that holds several data items or elements of the same data type
Add another language to your schema. Wit: Add another language to your schema. Without changing the basic structure of your schema, you can ensure it can be shared and used in different languages.
The list of attributes correspond to the: The list of attributes correspond to the column headers of a data file.
Select the division and group that best: Select the division and group that best reflects how you would classify your schema.
The name of the schema. It is recommende: The name of the schema. It is recommended to use a more general name rather than one that identifies a specific dataset or experiment.
The description of the schema that will: The description of the schema that will help yourself and others determine what kind of data the schema describes.
This program lets you create OCA schema: This program lets you create OCA schema templates.
A well formed template MUST include: A well formed template MUST include:
There are one or more blank entries in t: There are one or more blank entries in the following field(s):
Label: Label
This is the language specific label for: This is the language specific label for an attribute.
This is a language specific description: This is a language specific description of the attribute and should contain information that will help dataset users understand necessary details about each attribute.
Toggles between the one or more language: Toggles between the one or more languages used in the schema.
You indicated in the previous step that: You indicated in the previous step that one or more attributes is a list. Please add entry codes for the same:
The entry choices for the schema. These: The entry choices for the schema. These will be what is recorded in the dataset and so can be simple entry codes.
A longer and more user-friendly language: A longer and more user-friendly language specific label for each entry code. This label will not be recorded in the dataset but can be used at the time of data entry to help users enter codes.
Check for each attribute where the data: Check for each attribute where the data entry cannot be left empty in a dataset.
Note: None of this data will be uploaded: Note: None of this data will be uploaded to a server and all processing happens on device.

Select the formatting rule that applies: Select the formatting rule that applies to data for each attribute.
All format rules are documented in the: All format rules are documented in the
Request a new format to be added by: Request a new format to be added by
raising an issue in the repository: raising an issue in the repository
Entry limits can only be created for att: Entry limits can only be created for attributes with an array DataType.
Applies only to array DatatTypes. Descri: Applies only to array DatatTypes. Describes the number of occurrences of an element.
NOTE: Please leave blank to not specify: NOTE: Please leave blank to not specify a min or max value
For each attribute you can specify the e: For each attribute you can specify the exact, minimum or maximum (or both minimum and maximum) number of entries allowed in a data record. Data types should be arrays to accept more than one entry.
The minimum value must be less than the: The minimum value must be less than the maximum value
All entries must be positive integers: All entries must be positive integers
All entries must be valid integers: All entries must be valid integers
The details of the schema including attr: The details of the schema including attribute names and their features as well as language specific information.
Language specific information describing: Language specific information describing general schema information.

To make it easier to upload a schema you: To make it easier to upload a schema you can drag and drop your existing dataset that you are creating the schema for. This schema should be in JSON format
To make it easier to upload a dataset yo: To make it easier to upload a dataset you can drag and drop your existing dataset that you are creating the schema for. This dataset should be in table format as an Excel or .csv format
To make it easier to create a schema you:
To make it easier to create a schema you can drag and drop your existing dataset that you are creating the schema for. This dataset should be in table format as an Excel or .csv format. The first row must contain the column headers (aka attribute names). 
 
 Note that no data leaves your device, and no data is uploaded to a server. All the processing to copy the column headers (attribute names) into the draft schema happens on your device.
